issue.title: [BUG]: Custom pipeline not working (classification)

repository.name: pycaret
repository.description: An open-source, low-code machine learning library in Python

issue.body:
### pycaret version checks

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported [here](https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret/issues).

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret/releases) of pycaret.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the develop branch of pycaret (pip install -U git+https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret.git@develop).


### Issue Description

I tried an example with a custom pipeline and it works if done manually, but not when done in pycaret (classification). Reproducible example here: https://gist.github.com/ngupta23/0e73daeb409ae35e048baed49f32c096



### Reproducible Example

```python
import tsfresh
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score

from sktime.datasets import load_arrow_head
from sktime.transformations.panel.tsfresh import TSFreshFeatureExtractor

# Load all arrow head
arrow_X, arrow_y = load_arrow_head(return_type="numpy2d")
arrow_X = pd.DataFrame(arrow_X)
arrow_y = pd.DataFrame({"target": arrow_y})
arrow = pd.concat([arrow_X, arrow_y], axis=1)

## Custom Pipeline (Manual without Pycaret - Works!)

tsfresh = TSFreshFeatureExtractor(default_fc_parameters="minimal")
randf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
pipe = Pipeline(
    [
        ("transform", tsfresh),
        ("classifier", randf),
    ]
)
pipe.fit(arrow_X.values, arrow_y.values)

## Custom Pipeline with Pycaret (Does not work)

from pycaret.classification import ClassificationExperiment
tsfresh = TSFreshFeatureExtractor(default_fc_parameters="minimal")
custom_tx = ("transform", tsfresh)
exp = ClassificationExperiment()
exp.setup(data = arrow, target="target", custom_pipeline=custom_tx)
```


### Expected Behavior

`pycaret` should work with the custom pipeline step as it works manually.

### Actual Results

```python-traceback

----> 9 exp.setup(data = arrow, target="target", custom_pipeline=custom_tx)

17 frames
```

body:
I think I understand the problem here.

A 2D numpy array can be used as a representation of univariate `Panel` format, where rows correspond to indivieual series, or multivariate `Series` format, where rows correspond to time points.

The type inference of `sktime` ends up selecting the former and not the latter, which seems counterintuitive given the example.

This probably needs to be turned around, i.e., when receiving a 2D numpy array in a case where the scitype is ambiguous, it should be interpreted as a single multivariate series and not a panel of multiple univariate series.

(for context, I did not want to have 2D also being able to mean univariate `Panel`, but @TonyBagnall insisted on having this as a potential input for classifiers, which makes sense there, but leads to this situation as a potential resolution due to ambiguous type inference. The type inference clash is between `numpyflat` and `numpy2D` representations, the former being a `Panel` and the latter a `Series`.)

FYI @tvdboom, I think it comes from ambiguous type inference when applying any transformer to a 2D numpy array.

It should probably be interpreted as single multivariate series, and not a panel of multiple univariate series.

@fkiraly In this case, we want to extract the features for each individual series - so we can eventually classify them into categories. Based on that the output with numpy seems to be correct. We would like to get the same output with pandas input as well. Could you clarify what change has to be made and where?

@fkiraly So maybe use this from your example folder instead?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33585645/168285195-ad550a18-46bd-470d-aafc-0e3dd3c5ff44.png)

Wait, you think the output in the `numpy` case is correct and the output in the `pandas` case is not what you want??

In that case, this looks like user error then.

If you want to pass multiple series in `sktime`, you have to do it in one of the panel formats, see section 1.2 of this notebook
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/examples/AA_datatypes_and_datasets.ipynb
for three options how you can format your data.

You can use, amongst others:
* `pandas`, but with a two-level row multiindex (series index, time)
* 3D `numpy` arrays (series index, variable index, time index)

reduced example that does not involve sklearn

```python
import pandas as pd

from sktime.datasets import load_arrow_head
from sktime.transformations.panel.tsfresh import TSFreshFeatureExtractor

# Load all arrow head
arrow_X, arrow_y = load_arrow_head(return_type="numpy2d")
arrow_X = pd.DataFrame(arrow_X)
arrow_y = pd.DataFrame({"target": arrow_y})

t = TSFreshFeatureExtractor(default_fc_parameters="minimal")

results_np = t.fit_transform(arrow_X.values, arrow_y.values)
results_np

results_pd = t.fit_transform(arrow_X, arrow_y)
results_pd
```

> FYI @tvdboom, I think it comes from ambiguous type inference when applying any transformer to a 2D numpy array.
> 
> It should probably be interpreted as single multivariate series, and not a panel of multiple univariate series.

I would argue the opposite, 2D array should by default be a collection of univariate series!

> I would argue the opposite, 2D array should by default be a collection of univariate series!

I knew you would say that...
I think there is a clear discrepancy on the "should" here between TSC users and forecasting users.

On another note, the source of the bug is a completely broken series-vs-panel conversion logic for numpy data containers:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2638

The index sequence was being flipped around the completely wrong way.

Really easy to get confused due to the difference in sequence between TSC favoured specification and sklearn style specification:
```
numpy2D = (time, variables)  # sklearn style
numpy3D = (instances, variables, time)  # TSC/Tony style
```

@TonyBagnall, what have you done!

It is, in fact, like that in the classification notebook! I.e., 2D numpy array interpreted as a panel of univariate series and not as a single multivariate series! 😱 
(cell 9, the one with the `sklearn` pipeline)

How do we sort that out then?
I thought we agreed to not use the `numpyflat` specification, except internally!

issue.title: [ENH] type convention clash between transformers and classifiers in case of 2D numpy input

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
There is a type convention clash between transformers and classifiers, as currently in sktime.
😱 

Transformers are consistent with the forecasting module and the datatypes module (convention A), but classifiers are not (convention B).

The clash is as how 2D `numpy` arrays are being interpreted.

Classifiers (convention B) interpret them as a panel of univariate series, (n_series, n_timepoints).
This is in accordance with the `numpyflat` mtype that I thought we were using only internally.

Everything else (convention A) interpret them as a single multivariate series, (n_timepoints, n_variables).
This is in accordance with the `numpy2D` mtype.

Convention A is also consistent with the datatypes notebook that contains the preferred specifications.

What should we do?

I think we need to be consistent here, or we get weirdness in pipelines, such as in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2637. Non-uniform conventions on data representations will leave us in a situation where transformers are either compatible with one or the other, but they cannot be with both.

body:
> In that case, this looks like user error then.

correction: user frustration due to whas is imo a highly problematic `sktime` internal inconsistency in handling and interpreting the 2D numpy type
Can this be closed? It seems to be superseded by #2640 and not a TSFresh specific issue.
